trips.name: Grand Canyon National Park
trips.description: Vast red rock canyon carved by the Colorado River.
trips.long_description: Stretching 277 miles long and over a mile deep, the Grand Canyon reveals nearly two billion years of Earth's geological history through its colorful layered rock formations. Carved by the relentless flow of the Colorado River, this UNESCO World Heritage Site offers breathtaking viewpoints, challenging hiking trails, and a window into the forces that shaped our planet. From sunrise at Mather Point to sunset over Desert View, each moment reveals new shades of red, gold, and violet across its vast expanse. The park is home to diverse wildlife, ancient Native American dwellings, and one of the most awe-inspiring natural landscapes on Earth.

trips.name: Niagara Falls
trips.description: Massive waterfalls between the US and Canada.
trips.long_description: Niagara Falls is one of the most famous and powerful natural wonders on the planet, straddling the border between the United States and Canada. Comprised of three separate waterfalls — Horseshoe Falls, American Falls, and Bridal Veil Falls — it thunders with over 3,000 tons of water cascading every second. Visitors can experience its majesty up close aboard the Maid of the Mist boat tour or view the spectacle from observation decks surrounded by mist and rainbows. The surrounding region also offers scenic trails, light shows, and the charming town of Niagara-on-the-Lake, blending natural power with romantic beauty and family-friendly attractions.

trips.name: Carhenge
trips.description: Stonehenge replica made entirely from vintage cars.
trips.long_description: Carhenge, located near Alliance, Nebraska, is a whimsical and creative tribute to England’s Stonehenge — but with a distinctly American twist. Built in 1987 by artist Jim Reinders, the monument is composed of 38 vintage automobiles arranged in the same proportions and layout as the original prehistoric structure. Each car is painted gray to mimic the color of weathered stone, giving the illusion of a metallic megalithic site. Carhenge celebrates both the ingenuity of modern art and America’s deep car culture, standing as a symbol of humor, imagination, and rural creativity that attracts thousands of curious visitors every year.

trips.name: Machu Picchu
trips.description: Lost Incan city hidden in the Peruvian Andes.
trips.long_description: Perched high in the Andes Mountains of Peru, Machu Picchu is one of the world’s most iconic archaeological sites. Built in the 15th century under the Inca emperor Pachacuti, this 'Lost City' remained hidden from the outside world until its rediscovery in 1911. The site’s intricate stonework, terraces, and temples display the Incas’ mastery of engineering and architecture, all without the use of mortar. Surrounded by misty peaks and lush greenery, Machu Picchu offers not only a glimpse into the ancient world but also breathtaking panoramic views of the Urubamba Valley below. Today it stands as a symbol of human creativity harmoniously integrated with nature.

trips.name: Taj Mahal
trips.description: India’s iconic white marble mausoleum of eternal love.
trips.long_description: The Taj Mahal, located in Agra, India, is one of the most admired architectural masterpieces in the world. Built between 1631 and 1648 by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his beloved wife Mumtaz Mahal, the monument stands as an everlasting symbol of love and devotion. Its perfectly symmetrical structure, shimmering white marble, and intricate floral inlays create a breathtaking harmony of art and geometry. The Taj Mahal changes color with the light — glowing pink at sunrise, ivory white at noon, and golden under moonlight. Surrounded by tranquil gardens and reflecting pools, it attracts millions of visitors from around the world every year.

trips.name: Eiffel Tower
trips.description: The symbol of Paris and one of the most visited monuments in the world.
trips.long_description: The Eiffel Tower, completed in 1889 for the Exposition Universelle in Paris, is an engineering marvel and a global icon of romance. Designed by Gustave Eiffel, the 324-meter iron lattice structure was initially met with criticism but quickly became the pride of France. Visitors can climb or take elevators to observation decks offering panoramic views of the City of Light — from the Seine River to the distant Sacré-Cœur. Illuminated by over 20,000 lights at night, the tower is a living symbol of innovation, elegance, and the timeless charm of Parisian culture. More than 7 million people visit it each year, making it one of the most beloved monuments on Earth.
